School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 PR China Finding a robust cobalt catalyst with highly exposed metallic, active sites has been challenging but highly desirable. Extending our in-situ hybridization route, herein we prepared a highly dispersed and accessible CoO x #TiO2 catalyst via interface engineering induced by the benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC). At the optimized content of BTC (molar ratio of BTC/Co=1), the introduced BTC exerted two vital roles in providing active cobalt center, one is retarding the creation of hard-reducible cobalt titanate (CoTiO3) to facilitate the reduction of CoOx species, the other is stabilizing the anatase phase and retaining a relatively high surface area to well-disperse the cobalt nanoparticles. As a result, the selected CoO x #TiO2, affording a large number of accessible metallic cobalt sites, showed an excellent furfuryl alcohol productivity of 31 gFOL·gCo -1·h-1 at 140 oC and 2.0 MPa, which is among the top values reported by other scientists. Synopsis The BTC ligands can stabilize the anatase and retard the creation of hard-reducible cobalt titanate (CoTiO3), affording high number of accessible metallic cobalt species. An excellent FOL productivity of 31 gFUR·gCo -1·h-1 at 140 oC and 2.0 MPa was achieved. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Interface-interaction In-situ hybridization Cobalt catalyst Furfural hydrogenation Benzene tricarboxylic acid Reducibility Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In the scenario of industrial chemical production, cobalt catalysts occupy a broader position in the hydrogenation of chemicals (e.g., CO [1], CO2 [2], biomass-derived aldehyde[3], aromatic hydrocarbons [4], etc.). A high-performance supported cobalt catalyst holding sufficient metallic active sites is typically realized by downsizing the particles to nano-scale ensembles (<10 nm), where high metal surface area along with numerous defect sites (terrace, corner, etc.) are acquired [5]. However, these energetic ensembles are likely to aggregate driven by the inherently high surface energy and magnetic attribution and thereby subject to severe activity loss. Numerous academic groups have so far documented a variety of protocols, including space confinement [6,7], ligand immobilization [8], alloy other metals [5,9], and so on, to address these drawbacks. Researchers have recognized from their findings that interface engineering, which derives from the interactions between the supports and active components, exerts its vital role in retaining the small particle size of active metal components [10]. It would be highly desirable to conceive a tunable strategy to intensify the metal-support interactions. To attain highly dispersed CuO#SiO2 catalysts, our group has devised an in-situ hybridization route in which the metal precursors (metal ions), support precursors (tetra orthosilicate or tetra butyl titanate), and organic ligands are all mixed simultaneously and in-situ self-assembled into hybrid composites [11–13]. Beneficial to the homogeneous hybridization fashion, the almost full contact between the copper and support allowed for an intensified metal-support interaction. We thus expect that such an in-situ hybridization approach can be extended to achieve a robust and highly dispersed TiO2-supported cobalt catalyst for hydrogenation. Besides the metal dispersion, the reduced state of cobalt species poses another great concern to its activity. Since the cobalt with a metallic state is the active center for hydrogenation, the cobalt catalysts require activation by hydrogen reduction at as high as 500–600 °C to ensure a high reduction degree [14,15]. As was already indicated above, increasing the metal-support interaction can promote metal dispersion, but also raise reduction difficulty accordingly. Furthermore, due to the low free formation energy value of CoTiO3 (−18.41 kJ/mol) [16], the cobalt ions and titania are apt to coordinate to form CoTiO3 species that difficult to reduce, especially when a strong interplay between them [17], [18], causing as high reduction temperature as up to 700–800 oC. Excessive high reduction temperature could raise several unfavorable issues of metal sintering, operation complexity, and energy-consuming. Therefore, a delicate balance between metal dispersion and reducibility should be carefully considered to acquire a high-performance and reliable cobalt catalyst. As is mentioned in our in-situ hybridization process, the benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC) was introduced to serve as MOF ligand and mesoporosity initiator. In several scientists’ reports, the organic with carboxyl groups could have a strong interaction with the titania surface by molecular adsorption or coordination [19], as manifested by intensified binding [20], oxygen vacancies transfer [21], etc. Thus, we assume the introduced organic ligands (BTC) could serve as reducibility adjustors by affecting the interface interaction between cobalt and titanium ions. Hence two aspects of interface engineering could be brought by in-situ hybridization synthesized route, one being that the close contact between the cobalt ions and titania precursors enables a strengthened cobalt-titania interactions to yield a homogeneous metal dispersion, and the other being that the introduced organic ligands can modulate the reducibility of metal species. In this work, we extended our in-situ hybridization strategy to access a highly exposed and robust cobalt catalyst for furfural (FUR) hydrogenation, a typical model reaction in biomass valorization. By varying the content of BTC in the hybrid composite, the metal dispersion and reducibility can be controllably tuned by an inherent interface interaction between the cobalt species and titania. Controlled experiments and characterizations were performed to correlate the catalytic activity with the special role of BTC. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were purchased commercially (Macklin, China) and used without further purification. Scheme 1 illustrates the fabrication route for the CoOx#TiO2 catalyst, detailed experimental procedure are as follow: Synthesis of Co-BTC#Titania hybrid composite. According to the method previously reported by our group [11,12], the synthetic process for the hybrid gel is as follows. Firstly 0.25 g cobalt nitrate hydrate (Co(NO3)2•6 H2O) and 2 g titanium butoxide (TBT) were dissolved together in 10 mL ethanol. Then 0.25 g 1, 3, 5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC) was dissolved in 10 mL ethanol and added into the mixed solution. The final mixture contained components with a molar ratio of Co: BTC: TBT: EtOH = 1:1.38:6.84:384. Then the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 150 °C for 24 h. The as-obtained hybrid gel was collected and dried at 60 °C overnight, labeled as Co-BTC#Titania, where the symbol # stands for the manner of hybridization. Preparation of CoO x #TiO 2 catalysts. The as-prepared Co-BTC#Titania was placed in a muffle furnace, calcinated at 500 °C for 4 h, and then cooled to room temperature. The calcination of CoOx#TiO2 catalysts were performed in normal room air. The relative humidity during the calcination process was approximate ∼50 %. The as-obtained samples were denoted as CoO x #TiO2-b-n (n = 0, 0.5, 1 and 2), where the b-n stands for the molar ratio of BTC to Co(NO3)2. Commercial Co NPs (50–100 nm) were used as reference catalysts purchased from the Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Another reference catalyst, CoOx/TiO2-ref, with cobalt loading of 15 % was prepared using the impregnation method according to the method previously reported by Davis et al. [22]. 2.2 Structure characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a D/Max-IIIA X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation. The metallic element contents were obtained by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (Agilent 7800, USA). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a STA409PC thermogravimetric analyzer (Netzsch, German). The temperature range was 30–800 oC with a heating rate of 5 °C/min in a nitrogen atmosphere (25 mL/min). Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) was conducted on a Tensor 27 spectrometer (Bruker, USA) in the range of 400–4000 cm-1 with a resolution of 4 cm-1 to obtain IR spectra of the sample. Raman spectra were recorded in a Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution (Horiba, Japan) instrument. The micromorphology was obtained using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (Zeiss Sigma 300, German). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was carried out on a JEM-2010 microscope (JEOL, Japan) using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured with a Tristar 3010 isothermal nitrogen sorption analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) using a continuous adsorption procedure. The pore size distribution was calculated from the branch of desorption plots. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha (ThermoFisher, USA) spectrometer. Spectra were obtained using aluminum radiation (Al Kα = 1486.6 eV) operating at 72 W and a spot size of 400 µm. Under the background pressure lower than 2 × 10-7 mbar, survey scans spectra of pelletized samples were measured at constant pass energy of 200 eV and region scans at 50 eV. Charge referencing was measured against adventitious carbon (C 1 s at 284.8 eV). H2-TPR and H2-TPD were performed on Auto Chem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with a TCD detector. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation Studies on the hydrogenation of FUR toward furfuryl alcohol (FOL) were performed in a 50 mL autoclave (CF-0.05, HONGYI Instrument). Before the activity evaluation, the CoO x #TiO2-b-n was transferred to a tubular furnace and reduced by H2/N2 (10 %) at 600 oC for 4 h. In a typical experiment, 2 mmol of FUR, 50 mg of catalyst and 10 mL of ethanol were added into the autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, purged with H2 four times, and then pressurized with H2 to the required pressure (0.5–1 MPa). The autoclave was heated to the required temperature (100–140 oC), and the reaction was left for the required time (1–4 h). After the required time, the reactor was cooled, and the solution was transferred with 20 mL of ethanol. A certain amount of octane was then added as a standard internal substance. The samples were analyzed by GC (Shimadzu GC-2–14 C, FID) with a DM-WAX column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) and GC-MS (Thermal Trace GC Ultra with a Polaris Q ion trap mass spectrometer equipped with a TR-5MS capillary column). The calculation of FUR conversion, product selectivity, and productivity was based on the following equations. The carbon balance was well than 95 %. (1) FUR conversion ( % ) = 100 − moles of FUR residual moles of FUR initially × 100 (2) Selectivity ( % ) = moles of specific product sum of moles of detected organic compounds × 100 (3) P roductivity ( g FOL · g Co − 1 · h − 1 ) = mass of FOL produced mass of cobalt used × hours of reaction 3 Results and discussion 3.1 In-situ hybridization of Co-BTC and titania According to the route proposed in our previous work [13], Scheme 1 depicts the in-situ hybridization process for the Co-BTC#titania. The cobalt ions coordinate with the benzoic acid (BTC) to form the Co-BTC unit, while the tetra butyl titanate (TBT) proceeds through hydrolysis/condensation to form titania gel. Then the Co-BTC and titania are in-situ hybridized and self-assembled into a microsphere composite driven by hydrothermally aging. The resulting Co-BTC and hybrid composites’ appearance and morphology are shown in Fig. S1 and Fig. 1. The Co-BTC presents as uniformly dispersed microspheres with an average diameter of 1.22 µm. After hybridizing with the titania, the as-obtained Co-BTC#titania retains the microsphere morphology with a relatively rough surface, which seems more like an aggregation of nanoparticles with a mean size of 0.36 µm. Fig. 2a shows the XRD pattern of the synthesized Co-BTC and hybrid composite. The Co-BTC features a group of peaks at 10, 18, 37 and 48° of 2θ, which is distinct from the various forms of Co-BTC MOFs reported in the literature [23,24]. The Co-BTC#Titania preserves the feature peak at 10° of 2θ. In the FTIR spectra (Fig. 2b), several bands located at 1716 cm-1, 1624 cm-1, 1556 cm-1, 1452 cm-1, 1403 cm-1, 1182 cm-1, 1109 cm-1, etc., are found in the Co-BTC and Co-BTC#Titania, corresponding to the characteristic bands of the BTC ligand [25,26]. Observable peak shifts (1609→1629 cm-1 and 1403→1368 cm-1) occur on the Co-BTC and Co-BTC#Titania, which can be associated with the coordination between the BTC and cobalt [27]. The TG-DTG plots (Fig. 2c) provide additional evidence for the presence of Co-BTC within the titania matrix, where a weight loss of around 27 wt. % occurs at ∼400 °C, assigned to the pyrolysis of BTC ligands [11]. The comparatively high DTG temperature over the Co-BTC#Titania implies that the pyrolysis kinetics are regulated, which would impact the cobalt-titania interactions. These results predict the inter-play between the Co-BTC and titania. 3.2 Structural alteration in the CoO x #TiO2 by BTC ligands Undergoing the air calcination at 500 °C, the Co-BTC#Titania transforms into TiO2-supported cobalt oxide catalyst, CoO x #TiO2. We prepared a series of samples with various BTC content to investigate the effect of Co-BTC coordination on the cobalt-titania interaction. We labeled them as CoO x #TiO2-b-n, where n represents the molar ratio of BTC to cobalt. Fig. 3a witnesses the crystallite phase evolution of samples upon the increased BTC content. The anatase crystalline phase, represented by a collection of peaks at 24, 37, 48, 55, and 62° of 2θ [28], is seen in all these samples. Two well-defined peaks centered at 33 and 35.6 o of 2θ belong to the ilmenite phase of CoTiO3 [29]. Viewed from the magnified regional pattern (Fig. 3b), the CoTiO3 phase gradually decreases along with the addition of BTC, and vanishes on CoO x #TiO2-b1, then reappears at high BTC content. Accordingly, an imperceptible weak peak at 36.9 o of 2θ assigned to the Co3O4 specie [9] becomes prominent as the CoTiO3 vanishes. This result suggests that the addition of BTC can tune the crystalline composite, and the proper content of BTC impedes the creation of CoTiO3, indicating BTC's role in regulating interface interaction between titania and cobalt. The Raman spectra are sensitive to the vibration modes of CoO6 octahedra, even in amorphous CoTiO3, which can further support crystalline evolution in these samples (see Fig. 4a). Besides these adsorption models of anatase (Eg(1), Eg(2), Bg(1), Bg(2) and Eg(3)), two bands at ∼694 cm-1 and ∼335 cm-1 appear in all the samples (Fig. 4b), arising from the frequency vibrational mode of CoO6 octahedra [30]. Although the XRD hardly detects the CoTiO3 phase in CoO x #TiO2-b1, the Raman spectra discern its amorphous CoTiO3. Combining the XRD and Raman, we can conclude that the BTC content affects the creation of CoTiO3, which would further alter the CoO x reducibility due to the competitive coordination of cobalt ions. Then we performed the H2-TPR to compare the reducibility between these samples, as shown in Fig. 5a. In general [31,32], the reduction of cobalt oxides follows a typical two steps of Co3O4→CoO→Co°, where the first step occurs at a temperature < 400 °C, and the latter proceeds at 400–700 °C. Thus, we distinguished the TPR profile as α, β and γ regions, representing varied reducible species, and calculated their peak area in Fig. 5b. As expected, the presence of organic ligand BTC can affect the reducibility strongly. At a temperature lower than 400 oC (α region), the CoO x #TiO2-b0.5 and CoO x #TiO2-b1 held more prominent reduction peaks than the two others, suggesting their more easily reducible CoO x species. In the temperature range of 400–600 °C (β region), multiple reductions appear to depend on the cobalt-TiO2 interaction strength [9], and most of the CoO x species are reduced on these samples except for the CoO x #TiO2-b2. At a temperature larger than 600 °C (γ region), the CoOx#TiO2-b2 has a reduction peak assigned to the reduction of stable CoTiO3-like solid solution [18]. These results further demonstrate that the varied cobalt-titanium interaction induced by the BTC addition and the reduction behavior correlates well with the presence of CoTiO3. Accordingly, the CoO x #TiO2-b1 showing the lowest amount of CoTiO3 affords the most easy-reducible CoO x species. Fig. 6 shows the XPS spectra of various samples to investigate catalysts' electronic state and surface composition. The Co 2p3/2 spectra can be fitted by three individual peaks, assigned to the satellite shake-up peak (∼787 eV), Co2+ (∼782.5 eV), and Co3+ (∼780.5 eV) species, respectively [33,34]. Interestingly, we found the sample with low content of CoTiO3 (e.g., CoO x #TiO2-b0.5 and CoO x #TiO2-b1) has a relatively low binding energy; accordingly, the Ti 2p showing a 2p peak at 458.5 eV, shifts toward high binding energy for those ones. It indicates a charge transfer from the Ti atom to the Co due to the alteration in crystallite composition. Such electronic state alteration indirectly reflects the interaction between cobalt and titanium. In the O 1s spectra, the peak at 529, 531 and 533 eV can be assigned to the O-Ti bond, O-Co bond, and adsorbed oxygen species [23,35], respectively. The atomic ratios of Co/Ti on the surface of samples can be obtained from the XPS spectra, as shown in Table S1 of Supporting information, in which all the XPS-derived Co/Ti are smaller than the ICP-OES derived Co/Ti. This suggests that part of the CoO x species is inaccessible over these samples. The CoO x #TiO2-b1 has the highest surface molar ratio of Co/Ti, predicting its high accessibility of CoO x species overwhelming the others. 3.3 Pre-activation of CoO x #TiO2 by hydrogen reduction Before the activity evaluation, the CoO x #TiO2 catalysts need to be reduced into metallic states. We activated these CoO x #TiO2 catalysts by hydrogen reduction at 600 °C where most of the cobalt species can be reduced according to the finding in H2-TPR results. Underwent such a thermal activation, most part of the anatase phase is transformed into rutile due to the energy reconfiguration, as observed in the Fig. 7a, which may cause a drop in surface area. Surprisingly it is not for the case of CoO x #TiO2-b1, as it holds the anatase phase exclusively. For the CoO x #TiO2-b2, it even still has CoTiO3 phase, corresponding its hard reducibility. This result demonstrates the stabilization of anatase phase by the BTC ligands. In the magnified region profile of Fig. 7 b , the CoO x #TiO2-b1 shows a more broadened peak centered at 43° of 2θ, assignable to the metallic state of cobalt, than the other three samples, indicating its limited metal sintering. In other words, suitable BTC content can significantly improve the cobalt dispersion. Fig. 8a-b shows a type IV adsorption model with a hysteresis loop for these samples, suggesting the mesoporosity within these materials [36]. Increasing the BTC content, the onset of adsorption rising profile (indicated by the red dotted line) shifts to a high value of p/p 0 , along with total adsorption volume, indicating a change in pore size and surface area. Fig. 8c plots the porosity change upon the BTC content; as expected, both the surface area and pore size summit at the molar ratio of BTC/Co= 1, where the anatase phase is largely retained. A high surface area would be beneficial to the cobalt dispersion, as well as mass transportation during the reaction. The highly dispersed cobalt NPs loaded on the CoO x #TiO2-b1 can be visualized on HRTEM images ( Fig. 9a-c). The light grey region indicates the titania with a characteristic (101) lattice value of 0.305 nm [37]; the dark grey region having a domain size of 8–10 nm suggests the metallic cobalt nanoparticles, as justified by the (111) lattice value of 0.200 nm [23]. The corresponding HAADF images and element mapping (Fig. 9d-g) further confirm the homogeneous cobalt dispersion in CoO x #TiO2-b1. Hence, from the view of the hydrogenation catalyst, we selected the CoO x #TiO2-b1 as the optimized candidate for hydrogenation. To study the hydrogen adsorption capacity, the H2-TPD was conducted for the CoO x #TiO2-b-n after reduction at 600 oC by H2. In Fig. 10a, a broad hydrogen desorption peak located at 100–400 °C is observable for these reduced cobalt catalysts, and the peak area corresponding to their hydrogen adsorption capacity follows in the order of CoO x #TiO2-b1 >CoO x #TiO2-b0.5 >CoO x #TiO2-b2 ≈ CoO x #TiO2-b0. Considering the variance in surface area, we normalized the hydrogen adsorption capacity by surface area in Fig. 10b, which shows a similar volcanic plot. It illustrates that CoO x #TiO2-b1 still has the highest density of hydrogen adsorption sites, which may be ascribed to its abundant accessible metallic cobalt active sites, or enhanced hydrogen spillover ability [38]. Either contribution would be beneficial to the hydrogenation activity. From the above result and discussion, we can see that the in situ hybridization route enables a strong interaction between the titania and cobalt species, yet it likely to yield the CoTiO3 species that difficult to reduce during the thermal calcination. This is detrimental to the exposure of metallic cobalt sites available. Optimizing the molar ratio of BTC/Co can tune such cobalt-titania interaction and retard the CoTiO3 creation to promote reducibility. Besides, the presence of BTC can stabilize the anatase phase, retain a relatively high surface area to disperse the reduced cobalt nanoparticles. Both crucial contributions afford highly dispersed and accessible cobalt active sites on the support. 3.4 Selective hydrogenation of FUR to FOL We executed the FUR hydrogenation for the catalytic performance evaluation of CoO x #TiO2-b-n catalysts. The product derived from the FUR hydrogenation varies significantly upon the reaction pathway, which depends strongly on the catalyst used [39,40]. For the cobalt catalyst, the FOL is preferentially produced at the reaction temperature lower than 150 oC, while the tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL) is occasionally detected as a result of deep hydrogenation [3,15,41]. Scheme 2. At first, several blank and controlled experiments were conducted to identify the real active center for this reaction, as shown in Table 1. Under the given reaction condition (T = 140 oC, p H2 =2.0 MPa), the reaction ran without any catalyst or with titania support alone (Entry 1–2, Table 1), showing negligible conversion of FUR. When the reaction was catalyzed by Co NPs (Macklin, Shanghai), the FUR conversion reached 36 % with an almost 98 % of selectivity toward FOL; as the Co NPs were passivated by oxygen, the FUR was barely converted (Entry 3–4, Table 1). These results clarify that the active center for hydrogenation should be the cobalt with a reduced state, which has also been demonstrated by other scientists [42]. The CoOx/TiO2-ref showed a comparable conversion as the Co NPs, yet with a significantly high productivity of 23 gFOL·gCo -1·h-1 (Entry 5, Table 1). By means of support, the usage efficiency of cobalt can be vastly improved. Then we investigated the catalytic performance of these CoOx#TiO2-b-n catalysts, as presented in Fig. 11 and Entry 1–4 of Table S2. The CoO x #TiO2-b-n catalysts present a conversion evolution following a volcano-like trend (Fig. 11a), where the CoO x #TiO2-b1 summits the highest conversion of 56 %. As the reaction period was extended to 2 h (Entry 5, Table S2), completed conversion was achieved with a comparable high FOL yield of 31 gFOL/gCo·h-1. As the FOL was used as the substrate, negligible THFOL was detected (Entry 6, Table S2), suggesting the dominant product of FOL under the given reaction conditions, consistent with the results reported by Ramos et al. [41]. In an attempt to elucidate the structural properties-activity relationship, we normalized the FUR conversion rate with the catalysts’ hydrogen adsorption capacity, observing roughly constant values, as shown by the red circles connected by an almost horizontal dotted line. It verifies our assumption that the high number of accessible metallic cobalt sites determines the hydrogenation activity. Table 2 collects the current representative FOL production rates over the cobalt catalysts reported by other scientist groups. The CoO x #TiO2-b1 is amongst the top-performance of cobalt catalysts used in comparable reaction conditions. Furthermore, the CoOx#TiO2-b1 has good stability, which was confirmed by the regeneration test (Entry 7–8, Table S2 in Supporting information). After several repeated runs, the CoOx#TiO2-b1 can restore nearly ∼88 % of its initial activity by thermal regeneration; Fig. S2 suggests the slight change in the crystalline phase and metal dispersion for these spent and regenerated catalysts. Next, we selected the CoO x #TiO2-b1 to study the effect of reduction temperature, reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure on the catalytic performance. The CoO x #TiO2-b1 catalyst presents a volcano-like plot upon the increased reduction temperature, peaking around ∼600 oC with a high FOL selectivity (>98 %), seeing Fig. 12a. The limited reduction degree at low temperatures (<500 oC) and serious metal sintering at high temperatures (>600 oC) is responsible for the declined activity, respectively. In Fig. 12b, the reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure significantly impact the FUR conversion. The FUR conversion rises strikingly with the elevation of hydrogen pressure, especially at high temperatures (>140 oC). The same trend also is observed over the commercial cobalt NPs, seeing Fig. S3 of Supporting information. At the fixed p H2 = 2.0 MPa, we calculated the apparent activation energies (Ea), as shown in Fig. 12c, where a similar apparent activation energy (Ea) of ∼56 kJ/mol is given over the CoO x #TiO2 and commercial Co NPs. This result further supports the deduction that the increased number, instead of the strength of the active cobalt sites, is responsible for the enhanced activity of the CoO x #TiO2. 3.5 Possible mechanism for the BTC ligands in regulating the CoTiO 3 formation From the above results and analysis, we know that the crucial role of BTC in promoting the reducibility of CoO x #TiO2 is highly associated with the retarded creation of CoTiO3 which is difficult to reduce. Hence, a preliminary exploration was conducted to explain how the BTC retard the formation of CoTiO3. We firstly conducted the TG-DTG analysis for these as-prepared Co-BTC#Titania composites with various molar ratios of BTC/Cobalt. Fig. 13a summarizes the TG % and the highest DTG peak position/temperature (dictated by the red arrow in Fig. S4 , Supporting information) as a function of the BTC/Co molar ratio. Various pyrolysis kinetic of BTC ligands is observed, which may be originated from the diverse interaction between the BTC and titania or cobalt. Particularly, the lowest temperature (421 oC) recorded on the CoO x #TiO2-b1 predicts its weakened interplay at the optimized BTC/Co molar ratio. The modulated interaction among these organic/inorganic species would affect the crystal phase accordingly. We monitored the evolution of crystallite composition as a function of calcination temperature for these CoOx#TiO2 catalysts (See Fig. S5, Supporting information). For clarity, we collected the crystal phase proportion upon the elevation of calcination temperature for each sample, as presented in Fig. 13b-c. Summarizing these results, we interestingly found a close correlation between the anatase stability and CoTiO3 formation. In other words, at the optimized BTC content (molar ratio of BTCCo =1), the anatase phase can be preferentially formed and retained, showing a good ability to resist the creation of both CoTiO3 and rutile. Since the anatase phase is stable, the Co atoms require more energy to coordinate with Ti atoms to form the CoTiO3 phase. Therefore, the role of BTC in retarding the CoTiO3 creation can be recognized as stabilizing the anatase phase. Indeed, numerous literatures have supported that the hydroxyl/carboxyl groups of organic molecules can adsorb/coordinate on titania, leading to a strengthened interplay between them [19,20,46]. For example, Ettore’s group highlighted forming a short, strong hydrogen bond between the carboxyl group and anatase (101) surfaces. We depicted a schematic diagram to describe the role of the BTC ligand in regulating the CoO x #TiO2 reducibility in Fig. 14. The BTC ligands adsorb/coordinate onto the anatase surface by the hydrogen bond or other unknown fashion, stabilizing the anatase phase. Consequently, it weakens the cobalt-titania interface interaction and retard the formation of CoTiO3. Otherwise, too strong cobalt-titania interface interaction would give rise to the creation of CoTiO3 that difficult to reduce. 4 Conclusions We successfully extended our in-situ hybridization strategy to acquire a highly dispersed and accessible CoO x #TiO2 catalyst for the hydrogenation of FUR. The role of BTC ligands in regulating the reducibility and metal dispersion was symmetrically studied. At the optimized molar ratio of BTC/Co, the presence of BTC not only retard the creation of CoTiO3 to promote the catalyst’s reducibility but also retain a relatively high surface area to disperse the reduced cobalt nanoparticles. As a result, the optimized CoOx#TiO2-b1 having a high number of accessible active cobalt sites showed an excellent FOL production rate of 31 gFOL·gCo -1·h-1 at 140 oC and 2 MPa, which was among the top cobalt-based catalysts reported by other scientists. The origin of this BTC ligands induced interface engineering was preliminarily investigated, which is related to the stabilization of anatase by BTC, thus weakening the cobalt-titania interaction. This work could offer an effective strategy for constructing high-performance and robust cobalt catalysts for hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Finding a robust cobalt catalyst with highly exposed metallic, active sites has been challenging but highly desirable. Extending our in-situ hybridization route, herein we prepared a highly dispersed and accessible CoO x #TiO2 catalyst via interface engineering induced by the benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC). At the optimized content of BTC (molar ratio of BTC/Co=1), the introduced BTC exerted two vital roles in providing active cobalt center, one is retarding the creation of hard-reducible cobalt titanate (CoTiO3) to facilitate the reduction of CoOx species, the other is stabilizing the anatase phase and retaining a relatively high surface area to well-disperse the cobalt nanoparticles. As a result, the selected CoO x #TiO2, affording a large number of accessible metallic cobalt sites, showed an excellent furfuryl alcohol productivity of 31 gFOL·gCo -1·h-1 at 140 oC and 2.0 MPa, which is among the top values reported by other scientists. Synopsis The BTC ligands can stabilize the anatase and retard the creation of hard-reducible cobalt titanate (CoTiO3), affording high number of accessible metallic cobalt species. An excellent FOL productivity of 31 gFUR·gCo -1·h-1 at 140 oC and 2.0 MPa was achieved.
coredata.dc:title: Role of benzene tricarboxylic acid in regulating cobalt-titania interface-interaction to access highly dispersed cobalt nanoparticles catalyst
